<fragment>

***No Time to Die*** is a 2021 spy film and the twenty-fifth in the *James Bond* series produced by Eon Productions, starring Daniel Craig in his fifth and final portrayal of fictional British MI6 agent James Bond. It was directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga from a screenplay he co-wrote with Neal Purvis, Robert Wade and Phoebe Waller-Bridge, based on a story conceived by Purvis, Wade and Fukunaga. Léa Seydoux, Ben Whishaw, Naomie Harris, Jeffrey Wright, Christoph Waltz, Ralph Fiennes, and Rory Kinnear reprise their roles from previous films, with Rami Malek, Lashana Lynch, Billy Magnussen, Ana de Armas, David Dencik and Dali Benssalah also starring. In *No Time to Die*, Bond has left active service with MI6 and is recruited by the CIA to find a kidnapped scientist, which leads to a showdown with a powerful and vengeful adversary armed with a technology capable of killing millions. 


</fragment>
<fragment>

3. **^** Harwood also provided uncredited contributions to the script for *Goldfinger*. Dana Stevens contributed to the script of *The World Is Not Enough*, but was never formally credited for her work.[71][72]
4. **^** *No Time to Die* shares its title with a 1958 film directed by Terence Young, produced by Albert R. "Cubby" Broccoli and written by Richard Maibaum,[77][78][79] respectively the original director, producer and writer of *Dr. No*, *From Russia with Love* and *Thunderball*.[80][81][82]

<fragment>

Conversely, some critics found fault with the film. John Nugent of *Empire* criticised its length (2 hours and 43 minutes), asserting that the plotting and exposition in the middle third "doesn't justify that heaving runtime". Nevertheless, he thought the film "a fitting end to the Craig era".[250] Kyle Smith of *National Review* also criticised the film's length, and described it as "the least fun and most somber excursion in the entire Bond series".[251] Clarisse Loughrey of *The Independent* found it uneventful and disappointing: its core premise of a biological weapon of mass destruction was described as "generic spy nonsense", while she felt that Rami Malek "gives almost nothing to the role beyond his accent and stereotyped disfigurement makeup".[252]


</fragment>

148. **^** Grater, Tom (26 October 2019). "Bond 25: 'No Time To Die' Officially Wraps Ahead Of April 2020 Release". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on 5 October 2021. Retrieved 5 October 2021.`{{cite web}}`: CS1 maint: bot: original URL status unknown (link)

</fragment>
<fragment>

*No Time to Die* has an approval rating of 83% based on 425 reviews on the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 7.3/10. The critics consensus states: "It isn't the sleekest or most daring 007 adventure, but *No Time to Die* concludes Daniel Craig's franchise tenure in satisfying style."[237] Metacritic assigned the film a weighted average score of 68 out of 100 based on 67 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".[238] Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale, while those at PostTrak gave it an 83% positive score, with 63% saying they would definitely recommend it.[226]




</fragment>
<fragment>
168. **^** Chitwood, Adam (8 October 2021). "'No Time to Die' Ending Explained: Daniel Craig's Grand Finale". *TheWrap*. Archived from the original on 8 October 2021.
169. **^** Lang, Brent (2 June 2015). "James Bond Distribution Rights Coming Up For Grabs (Exclusive)". *Variety*. Archived from the original on 23 February 2022. Retrieved 23 February 2022.`{{cite web}}`: CS1 maint: bot: original URL status unknown (link)
170. **^** Barnes, Brooks (20 April 2017). "Five Studios' Mission: Winning the Distribution Rights to James Bond". *The New York Times*. Archived from the original on 29 July 2021. Retrieved 19 October 2021.
171. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Kilday, Gregg (24 May 2018). "Universal Wins James Bond International Distribution". *The Hollywood Reporter*. Archived from the original on 5 May 2019. Retrieved 8 May 2019.
172. **^** Rubin, Rebecca (22 January 2021). "'No Time to Die' Delays Release Date Again". *Variety*. Archived from the original on 22 August 2021. Retrieved 12 August 2021.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Barry Hertz of *The Globe and Mail* wrote that the film "makes sure that my eyes are following each and every oh-whoa stunt. As well as guaranteeing that I actually care about whether (or, really, how) Bond gets out of this one."[245] Mick LaSalle of the *San Francisco Chronicle* wrote that the film "takes its place among the best of the entire series", and concluded "Craig leaves the series in a mammoth, 163-minute extravaganza that audiences will be enjoying for decades. It's a lovely thing to see."[246] K. Austin Collins of *Rolling Stone* described the film as being "just fine: sometimes intriguing, sometimes not, sometimes boring, sometimes not", adding: "It's a bit more successful if we think of it instead as a tribute to the Craig era, and to the star himself."[247]


</fragment>

106. **^** McIntosh, Steven (4 December 2019). "What we learned from the first James Bond trailer". *BBC News*. Archived from the original on 7 December 2019. Retrieved 10 January 2020.
107. **^** Bond, Kimberley (8 January 2020). "James Bond No Time to Die full cast – new and returning characters list". *Radio Times*. Archived from the original on 13 January 2020. Retrieved 10 January 2020.

</fragment>

*No Time to Die* has an approval rating of 83% based on 425 reviews on the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 7.3/10. The critics consensus states: "It isn't the sleekest or most daring 007 adventure, but *No Time to Die* concludes Daniel Craig's franchise tenure in satisfying style."[237] Metacritic assigned the film a weighted average score of 68 out of 100 based on 67 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".[238] Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale, while those at PostTrak gave it an 83% positive score, with 63% saying they would definitely recommend it.[226]

As well as guaranteeing that I actually care about whether (or, really, how) Bond gets out of this one."[245] Mick LaSalle of the *San Francisco Chronicle* wrote that the film "takes its place among the best of the entire series", and concluded "Craig leaves the series in a mammoth, 163-minute extravaganza that audiences will be enjoying for decades. It's a lovely thing to see."[246] K. Austin Collins of *Rolling Stone* described the film as being "just fine: sometimes intriguing, sometimes not, sometimes boring, sometimes not", adding: "It's a bit more successful if we think of it instead as a tribute to the Craig era, and to the star himself."[247]

*Spectre* premiered at the Royal Albert Hall on 26 October 2015 and was theatrically released in conventional and IMAX formats in the United Kingdom that day, and in the United States on 6 November. The film received mixed reviews from critics, who praised the action sequences, cast performances (particularly Craig's and Bautista's), and the musical score, but criticised the pacing and formulaic narrative decisions. It grossed $880 million worldwide, making it the sixth-highest-grossing film of 2015 and the second-highest grossing *James Bond* film after *Skyfall,* unadjusted for inflation. The film's theme song, "Writing's on the Wall", won an Academy Award and Golden Globe for Best Original Song. The next film in the series, *No Time to Die,* was released in 2021.

***Spectre*** is a 2015 spy film and the twenty-fourth in the *James Bond* series produced by Eon Productions. Directed by Sam Mendes and written by John Logan, Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, and Jez Butterworth, it stars Daniel Craig as Bond, alongside Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux, Ben Whishaw, Naomie Harris, Dave Bautista, Monica Bellucci, and Ralph Fiennes. It was distributed by Sony Pictures Releasing. In the film, Bond learns of Spectre, an international crime organisation led by Ernst Stavro Blofeld (Waltz).

*Spectre* premiered at the Royal Albert Hall on 26 October 2015 and was theatrically released in conventional and IMAX formats in the United Kingdom that day, and in the United States on 6 November. The film received mixed reviews from critics, who praised the action sequences, cast performances (particularly Craig's and Bautista's), and the musical score, but criticised the pacing and formulaic narrative decisions. It grossed $880 million worldwide, making it the sixth-highest-grossing film of 2015 and the second-highest grossing *James Bond* film after *Skyfall,* unadjusted for inflation. The film's theme song, "Writing's on the Wall", won an Academy Award and Golden Globe for Best Original Song. The next film in the series, *No Time to Die,* was released in 2021.

***Spectre*** is a 2015 spy film and the twenty-fourth in the *James Bond* series produced by Eon Productions. Directed by Sam Mendes and written by John Logan, Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, and Jez Butterworth, it stars Daniel Craig as Bond, alongside Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux, Ben Whishaw, Naomie Harris, Dave Bautista, Monica Bellucci, and Ralph Fiennes. It was distributed by Sony Pictures Releasing. In the film, Bond learns of Spectre, an international crime organisation led by Ernst Stavro Blofeld (Waltz).

msg.content:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about Spectre (2015). It is the 24th James Bond film in the Eon Productions series. Here are the key details:

1. Basic Information:
- Released in 2015
- Directed by Sam Mendes
- Stars Daniel Craig as James Bond
- Written by John Logan, Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, and Jez Butterworth
- Budget: $245-300 million
- Box office: $880.7 million

2. Cast:
- Daniel Craig as James Bond
- Christoph Waltz
- Léa Seydoux
- Ben Whishaw
- Naomie Harris
- Dave Bautista
- Monica Bellucci
- Ralph Fiennes

3. Plot Overview:
The film follows James Bond as he uncovers the existence of Spectre, an international criminal organization led by Ernst Stavro Blofeld (played by Christoph Waltz).

4. Reception:
The film received mixed reviews from critics, who:
- Praised: Action sequences, cast performances (particularly Craig's and Bautista's), and musical score
- Criticized: Pacing and formulaic narrative decisions

5. Achievements:
- Became the sixth-highest-grossing film of 2015
- Second-highest grossing James Bond film after Skyfall
- The film's theme song "Writing's on the Wall" won both an Academy Award and Golden Globe for Best Original Song

6. Release:
- Premiered at the Royal Albert Hall on October 26, 2015
- Released in both conventional and IMAX formats
- Released in the United Kingdom on October 26, 2015
- Released in the United States on November 6, 2015

The film was followed by "No Time to Die" (2021) in the James Bond series.
